content.raw: I think that is something which can be added for convenience later. This is usable as is. Users may just need to publish extra static transform to rotate the frame.
content.html: I think that is something which can be added for convenience later. This is usable as is. Users may just need to publish extra static transform to rotate the frame.

content.raw:
I've reproduced your steps and got a similar result. But I have a question about the following:

> It would be convenient if we let users specify a custom camera frame to be published with the message, so it's not hardcoded to the sensor frame.

Is this more work that needs to be done, or is this ready to go as is?
content.html:
I've reproduced your steps and got a similar result. But I have a question about the following:

It would be convenient if we let users specify a custom camera frame to be published with the message, so it's not hardcoded to the sensor frame.

Is this more work that needs to be done, or is this ready to go as is?

content.raw:
The reason why the camera appears to be rotated 90 degrees is that Gazebo considers the camera to be looking at +X while ROS considers it to look at +Z. I believe it is the responsibility of whoever is receiving the data on the ROS side to publish the correct transforms to take that into account. It would be convenient if we let users specify a custom camera frame to be published with the message, so it's not hardcoded to the sensor frame.

---

## How to test

1. Use the pull requests mentioned above

1. Load [this world](https://bitbucket.org/snippets/chapulina/XeGArR) with the `-r` option:

        ign gazebo -v 4 -r camera_info.xml

1. Run the bridge like this:

        rosrun ros1_ign_bridge parameter_bridge /camera/image_raw@sensor_msgs/Image@ignition.msgs.Image /camera/camera_info@sensor_msgs/CameraInfo@ignition.msgs.CameraInfo /depth_camera/depth_image@sensor_msgs/Image@ignition.msgs.Image /depth_camera/camera_info@sensor_msgs/CameraInfo@ignition.msgs.CameraInfo

1. Open RViz and insert 2 `Camera` displays, one for `/camera/image_raw`, one for `/depth_camera/depth_image`

1. On RViz, change the fixed frame to `camera_model/camera_link/camera_sensor`

1. Publish a marker in the camera frame which should roughly match the box pose in the world

        rostopic pub /visualization_marker visualization_msgs/Marker '{header: {frame_id: "camera_model/camera_link/camera_sensor"}, id: 1, type: 1, action: 0, pose: {position: {z: 2}, orientation: {y: 0.38, w: 0.92}}, scale: {x: 1., y: 1., z: 1.}, color: {r: 1., g: 0., b: 1., a: 1.}, lifetime: 50000000000}'

1. On RViz, insert a `Marker` display for `/visualization_marker`

As shown below, the marker is more or less correctly projected onto both cameras.

I haven't managed to get the depth camera image itself show on RViz though, I think I need to choose the correct encoding options. But the depth camera info is working :smile:

![ign_camera_info.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/da5rgr4/images/3547381478-ign_camera_info.png)

![camera_info2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/da5rgr4/images/1362432954-camera_info2.png)
content.html:
The reason why the camera appears to be rotated 90 degrees is that Gazebo considers the camera to be looking at +X while ROS considers it to look at +Z. I believe it is the responsibility of whoever is receiving the data on the ROS side to publish the correct transforms to take that into account. It would be convenient if we let users specify a custom camera frame to be published with the message, so it's not hardcoded to the sensor frame.

How to test

  1. Use the pull requests mentioned above

  2. Load this world with the -r option:

    ign gazebo -v 4 -r camera_info.xml

  3. Run the bridge like this:

    rosrun ros1_ign_bridge parameter_bridge /camera/image_raw@sensor_msgs/Image@ignition.msgs.Image /camera/camera_info@sensor_msgs/CameraInfo@ignition.msgs.CameraInfo /depth_camera/depth_image@sensor_msgs/Image@ignition.msgs.Image /depth_camera/camera_info@sensor_msgs/CameraInfo@ignition.msgs.CameraInfo

  4. Open RViz and insert 2 Camera displays, one for /camera/image_raw, one for /depth_camera/depth_image

  5. On RViz, change the fixed frame to camera_model/camera_link/camera_sensor

  6. Publish a marker in the camera frame which should roughly match the box pose in the world

    rostopic pub /visualization_marker visualization_msgs/Marker '{header: {frame_id: "camera_model/camera_link/camera_sensor"}, id: 1, type: 1, action: 0, pose: {position: {z: 2}, orientation: {y: 0.38, w: 0.92}}, scale: {x: 1., y: 1., z: 1.}, color: {r: 1., g: 0., b: 1., a: 1.}, lifetime: 50000000000}'

  7. On RViz, insert a Marker display for /visualization_marker

As shown below, the marker is more or less correctly projected onto both cameras.

I haven't managed to get the depth camera image itself show on RViz though, I think I need to choose the correct encoding options. But the depth camera info is working
